row.Title: Director's Message
row.Author: J. Steven Landefeld
row.Description: Monthly message from BEA Director Steve Landefeld

row.Title: Taking Account
Business Situation: Final Estimates for the Third Quarter of 2005
row.Author: Christopher Swann
row.Description: Real GDP increased 4.1 percent after increasing 3.3 percent in the second quarter, reflecting accelerations in consumer spending and Federal Government spending. Corporate profits decreased $54.4 billion after increasing $59.3 billion.
row.Category: National, National income and product accounts (NIPAs)

row.Title: Real Inventories, Sales, and Inventory-Sales Ratios for Manufacturing and Trade for the Third Quarter of 2005
row.Description: The estimates, including the estimates of inventories for manufacturing by stage of fabrication, have been updated.
row.Category: National, Inventories, sales, and inventory-sales ratios for manufacturing and trade

row.Title: U.S. International Transactions: Third Quarter of 2005
row.Author: Mai-Chi Hoang, Matthew J. Argersinger
row.Description: The U.S. current-account deficit decreased $2.0 billion to $195.8 billion, mainly reflecting a decrease in net outflows for unilateral current transfers. In the financial account, net recorded financial inflows increased $122.3 billion to $272.9 billion.

row.Title: An Ownership-Based Framework of the U.S. Current Account, 1993-2004
row.Author: Jeffrey H. Lowe
row.Description: This updated supplement to the international transactions accounts highlights the participation of multinational companies in the international markets for goods and services through both cross-border trade and sales by local affiliates.

row.Title: State Personal Income: Third Quarter of 2005
row.Author: David G. Lenze
row.Description: Personal income for Louisiana, the state that was hardest hit by Hurricanes Katrina and Rita, fell 25 percent. Personal income for Mississippi and Alabama, which had less extensive damage, grew 0.8 percent. Personal income for all the other states grew 1.1 percent.

row.Title: Director's Message
row.Author: J. Steven Landefeld
row.Description: Monthly message from BEA Director Steve Landefeld

row.Title: Taking Account
Business Situation: Advance Estimates for the Fourth Quarter of 2005
row.Author: Christopher Swann
row.Description: Real GDP increased 1.1 percent after increasing 4.1 percent. Real disposable personal income increased 7.0 percent after decreasing 2.0 percent. In 2005, real GDP increased 3.5 percent after increasing 4.2 percent in 2004.
row.Category: National, National income and product accounts (NIPAs)
row.Supp1_Title: The Monthly Treasury Statement and BEA's Estimates of Federal Government Spending

row.Title: Gross Domestic Product: Revisions and Source Data
row.Author: Bruce T. Grimm, Teresa L. Weadock
row.Description: BEA uses a variety of source data to prepare its widely followed quarterly estimates of GDP. Each of the early estimates incorporates progressively more up-to-date source data. Overall, the picture of the economy shown by these estimates is little changed by later revisions.

row.Title: Taxation and Multinational Activity: New Evidence, New Interpretations
row.Author: Mihir A. Desai, C. Fritz Foley, James R. Hines Jr.
row.Description: Using data made available through a BEA program for outside researchers, three economists have produced a number of studies, summarized for the Survey, exploring the effect of various taxes on multinational firms' behavior.

row.Title: Director's Message
row.Author: J. Steven Landefeld
row.Description: Monthly message from BEA Director Steve Landefeld

row.Title: Taking Account
GDP and the Economy: Preliminary Estimates for the Fourth Quarter of 2005
row.Author: Christopher Swann
row.Description: Real GDP increased 1.6 percent after increasing 4.1 percent, primarily reflecting increases in inventory investment and consumer spending. Real disposable personal income increased 7.1 percent after decreasing 1.4 percent.
row.Category: National, National income and product accounts (NIPAs)

row.Title: Newly Available NIPA Table
row.Description: BEA releases the estimates of the changes in net stock of produced assets that show the effects of investment, depreciation, losses due to disasters, and holding gains on fixed assets and inventories.
row.Category: National, National income and product accounts (NIPAs)

row.Title: Federal Budget Estimates for Fiscal Year 2007
row.Author: Benjamin A. Mandel, Mary L. Roy
row.Description: Each year, BEA prepares estimates of Federal Government current receipts and expenditures that are based on the proposed Budget of the U.S. Government. The analysis of these translated estimates can be used to gauge the effects of the Federal budget on U.S. economic activity.
row.Supp1_Title: NIPA Estimates of the Federal Sector and the Federal Budget Estimates

row.Title: Schedule of BEA Exhibits
Director's Message
row.Author: J. Steven Landefeld
row.Description: Monthly message from BEA Director Steve Landefeld

row.Title: Taking Account
row.Description: Travel spending, Haiti earthquake, Web features

row.Title: GDP and the Economy: Final Estimates for the Fourth Quarter of 2005
row.Author: Christopher Swann
row.Description: Real GDP increased 1.7 percent after increasing 4.1 percent, reflecting increases in inventory investment and consumer spending. Real disposable personal income increased 6.7 percent after decreasing 1.4 percent. Corporate profits increased $185.8 billion after decreasing $54.4 billion.
row.Category: National, National income and product accounts (NIPAs)

row.Title: Government Receipts and Expenditures: Estimates for the Fourth Quarter of 2005
row.Author: Andrew E. Vargo
row.Description: Net government saving increased $115.5 billion to -$298.8 billion, reflecting an upturn in receipts and an acceleration in expenditures. Net Federal Government saving increased $119.3 billion to -$288.6 billion. Net state and local government saving decreased $3.8 billion to -$10.2 billion.
row.Category: National, National income and product accounts (NIPAs)

row.Title: Real Inventories, Sales, and Ratios: Fourth Quarter of 2005
row.Description: The estimates, including estimates of inventories for manufacturing by stage of fabrication, have been updated.
row.Category: National, Inventories, sales, and inventory-sales ratios for manufacturing and trade

row.Title: U.S. International Transactions: Fourth Quarter of 2005
row.Author: Mai-Chi Hoang, Renee M. Sauers
row.Description: The U.S. current-account deficit increased $39.5 billion to $224.9 billion, mostly as a result of an increase in net outflows for unilateral current transfers and an increase in the deficit on goods. In the financial account, net recorded financial inflows decreased $18.8 billion to $235.0 billion.

row.Title: U.S. International Transactions in 2005
row.Author: Christopher L. Bach
row.Description: The U.S. current-account deficit increased $136.8 billion to $804.9 billion, mainly reflecting an increase in the deficit on goods. In the financial account, net recorded financial inflows increased $216.4 billion to $801.0 billion.

row.Title: BEA Regional Program Outreach in 2006
row.Description: BEA's regional economic accounts provide detailed estimates of gross state product and personal income for states, counties, and metropolitan areas. To help users better understand and use these accounts, BEA participates in various conferences and workshops around the country.

row.Title: State Personal Income: Fourth Quarter of 2005 and Per Capita Income for 2005
row.Author: David G. Lenze
row.Description: Personal income for the Nation grew 2.3 percent, reflecting a rebound in several states from dramatic hurricane-related declines in the third quarter. Per capita personal income slowed, increasing 4.6 percent after increasing 5.0 percent.

row.Title: Director's Message
row.Author: J. Steven Landefeld
row.Description: Monthly message from BEA Director Steve Landefeld

row.Title: Taking Account
GDP and the Economy: Advance Estimates for the First Quarter of 2006
row.Author: Christopher Swann
row.Description: Real GDP increased 4.8 percent after increasing 1.7 percent, reflecting an acceleration in consumer spending, an upturn in Federal Government spending, and accelerations in business investment in equipment and software and in exports.
row.Category: National, National income and product accounts (NIPAs)

row.Title: Note on the Returns for Domestic Nonfinancial Corporations in 1960-2005
row.Description: The profitability of these corporations continued to increase. The before-tax rate of return on capital increased 10.1 percent in 2005 after increasing 9.2 percent in 2004. The after-tax rate of return on capital increased 7.5 percent after increasing 7.4 percent.
row.Category: National, National income and product accounts (NIPAs)

row.Title: Annual Industry Accounts: Advance Estimates for 2005
row.Author: Thomas F. Howells III, Kevin B. Barefoot
row.Description: U.S. economic growth reflected strong, but slower, growth in both the private services-producing and goods-producing sectors and a slight acceleration in prices.

row.Title: Errata: State Personal Income for 2003-2005
row.Description: The estimates of four components of personal income that were published in the April Survey were incorrect.

row.Title: Local Area Personal Income for 2002-2004
row.Author: David Lenze
row.Description: Personal income in all but five metropolitan areas increased in 2004. Per capita personal income in all but seven metropolitan areas increased.

row.Title: A Primer: Accessing BEA Direct Investment Data Interactively
row.Description: BEA's Web site now provides a service that allows users to interactively access detailed time-series data on U.S. Direct Investment Abroad, Foreign Direct Investment in the United States, activity by U.S. multinational companies (MNCs), and activity by U.S. affiliates of foreign MNCs.

row.Title: Director's Message
row.Author: J. Steven Landefeld
row.Description: Monthly message from BEA Director Steve Landefeld

row.Title: Taking Account
GDP and the Economy: Preliminary Estimates for the First Quarter of 2006
row.Author: Christopher Swann
row.Description: Real GDP increased 5.3 percent after increasing 1.7 percent, reflecting an acceleration in consumer spending, an acceleration in exports, an upturn in Federal Government spending, and an acceleration in equipment and software. Corporate profits slowed.
row.Category: National, National income and product accounts (NIPAs)

row.Title: Government Receipts and Expenditures: Estimates for the First Quarter of 2006
row.Author: Andrew E. Vargo
row.Description: Net government saving increased $96.4 billion to -$216.4 billion. Net Federal Government saving increased $66.7 billion to -$236.0 billion. Net state and local government saving increased $29.8 billion to $19. 6 billion.
row.Category: National, National income and product accounts (NIPAs)

row.Title: U.S. Travel and Tourism Satellite Accounts for 2002-2005
row.Author: Peter Kuhbach, Bradlee A. Herauf
row.Description: The tourism industry grew for the fourth year in a row. Real output of goods and services grew 4.9 percent in 2005, a deceleration from the strong 6.7-percent growth in 2004.
row.Category: Industry, Travel and tourism satellite accounts

row.Title: Foreign Direct Investment in the United States: New Investment in 2005
row.Author: Lawrence R. McNeil
row.Description: Outlays by foreign investors to acquire or establish U.S. businesses increased $0.6 billion to $86.8 billion despite a significant increase in merger and acquisition activity. Outlays to acquire existing businesses continued to exceed outlays to establish new businesses.
row.Category: International, Foreign direct investment in the United States

row.Title: Subject Guide for January-June 2006
row.Description: This guide lists the articles and other information that were published in these issues of the Survey.

row.Title: Director's Message
row.Author: J. Steven Landefeld
row.Description: Monthly message from BEA Director Steve Landefeld

row.Title: Taking Account
GDP and the Economy: Final Estimates for the First Quarter of 2006
row.Author: Christopher Swann
row.Description: Real GDP increased 5.6 percent after increasing 1.7 percent, reflecting an acceleration in consumer spending, an acceleration in exports, an upturn in Federal Government spending, and an acceleration in equipment and software. Corporate profits slowed.
row.Category: National, National income and product accounts (NIPAs)

row.Title: Real Inventories, Sales, and Inventory-Sales Ratios for Manufacturing and Trade for the First Quarter of 2006
row.Description: These estimates, including estimates of inventories for manufacturing by stage of fabrication, have been updated.
row.Category: National, Inventories, sales, and inventory-sales ratios for manufacturing and trade

row.Title: The International Investment Position of the United States at Yearend 2005
row.Author: Elena L. Nguyen
row.Description: The net international investment position at current cost was -$2,693.8 billion; in 2004, it was -$2,360.8 billion. The change was mainly due to record private net foreign purchases of U.S. securities and to depreciation of most major foreign currencies against the dollar.

row.Title: Direct Investment Positions for 2005: Country and Industry Detail
row.Author: Jennifer L. Koncz, Daniel R. Yorgason
row.Description: The historical-cost position of U.S. direct investment abroad increased 1 percent after increasing 16 percent in 2004, and the position of foreign direct investment in the United States increased 8 percent after increasing 9 percent.
row.Category: International, Direct investment positions: Country and industry detail

row.Title: Annual Revision of the U.S. International Accounts for 1995-2005
row.Author: Christopher L. Bach
row.Description: Each year, these estimates of U.S. transactions and of the U.S. international investment position are revised to incorporate statistical and methodological changes.

row.Title: How BEA Aligns and Augments Source Data From the U.S. Treasury Department for Inclusion in the International Transactions Accounts
row.Description: Each year, the estimates of financial-account flows in the international transactions accounts, which are based on Treasury Department data, are adjusted to align the estimates with balance-of-payments concepts and to close gaps in coverage.

row.Title: U.S. International Transactions: First Quarter of 2006
row.Author: Renee M. Sauers, Matthew J. Argersinger
row.Description: The U.S. current-account deficit decreased $14.4 billion, reflecting decreases in net unilateral current transfers and the deficit on goods and a shift to a surplus on income. In the financial account, net recorded financial inflows decreased $85.1 billion to $157.6 billion.

row.Title: Gross State Product: Advance Estimates for 2005 and Revised Estimates for 1998-2004
row.Author: Clifford H. Woodruff III, Sharon D. Panek, Eric C. Erickson
row.Description: Growth in real gross state product for the Nation slowed to 3.5 percent from 4.2 percent in 2004. Growth slowed in most states; 8 of the 10 fastest growing states were in the Rocky Mountain or Far West region.

row.Title: State Personal Income: First Quarter of 2006
row.Author: David G. Lenze
row.Description: Personal income for the Nation grew 1.4 percent after growing 1.9 percent in the fourth quarter of 2005, reflecting a slowdown in property income.

row.Title: Director's Message
row.Author: J. Steven Landefeld
row.Description: Monthly message from BEA Director Steve Landefeld

row.Title: Taking Account
GDP and the Economy: Advance Estimates for the Second Quarter of 2006
row.Author: Christopher Swann
row.Description: Real GDP increased 2.5 percent after increasing 5.6 percent. The deceleration primarily reflected downturns in consumer spending for durable goods and in business investment in equipment and software. Real disposable personal income increased 1.0 percent after increasing 1.7 percent.
row.Category: National, National income and product accounts (NIPAs)
row.Supp1_Title: Gross Domestic Product: Revisions and Source Data

row.Title: Annual Revision of the National Income and Product Accounts: Annual Estimates for 2003-2005 and Quarterly Estimates for 2003:I-2006:I
row.Author: Eugene P. Seskin, Shelly Smith
row.Description: For 2003-2005, real GDP growth averaged 3.2 percent, 0.3 percentage point less than in the previous estimates. For 2003:I-2006:I, real GDP growth averaged 3.6 percent, 0.2 percentage point less than in the previous estimates.
row.Category: National, National income and product accounts (NIPAs)

row.Title: National Income and Product Accounts Tables
row.Description: The revised annual, quarterly, and monthly estimates from the annual NIPA revision are presented in these tables. Advance estimates for the second quarter of 2006 and for June 2006 are included.
row.Category: National, National income and product accounts (NIPAs)

row.Title: GDP and Other Major NIPA Series for 1929-2006: II
row.Description: Historical estimates of GDP and its components in current dollars, in chained dollars, and in chain-type quantity and price indexes are presented as part of the annual NIPA revision. This series includes estimates of national income and personal income.
row.Category: National, National income and product accounts (NIPAs)

row.Title: U.S. Affiliates of Foreign Companies: Operations in 2004
row.Author: Thomas W. Anderson, William J. Zeile
row.Description: Growth in the current-dollar value added of majority-owned nonbank affiliates picked up, increasing 8 percent after increasing 3 percent in 2003. Employment of these affiliates continued to decline, decreasing 2 percent after decreasing 3 percent in 2002 and in 2003.
row.Category: International, Foreign direct investment in the United States

row.Title: Director's Message
row.Author: J. Steven Landefeld
row.Description: Monthly message from BEA Director Steve Landefeld

row.Title: Taking Account
GDP and the Economy: Preliminary Estimates for the Second Quarter of 2006
row.Author: Christopher Swann
row.Description: Real GDP increased 2.9 percent after increasing 5.6 percent. The deceleration reflected a deceleration in consumer spending for durable goods and downturns in business investment in equipment and software and Federal Government spending. Corporate profits slowed.
row.Category: National, National income and product accounts (NIPAs)

row.Title: Government Receipts and Expenditures: Estimates for the Second Quarter of 2006
row.Author: Erin M. Ludlow
row.Description: Net government saving increased $34.9 billion to -$99.4 billion. Net Federal Government saving increased $19.8 billion to -$127.2 billion. Net state and local government saving increased $15.1 billion to $27.8 billion.
row.Category: National, National income and product accounts (NIPAs)

row.Title: Newly Available NIPA Tables
row.Description: Estimates of government spending by function, changes in net stock of produced assets, the relationship between NIPA and USDA net farm income measures, and the relationship between NIPA personal income and IRS adjusted gross income-reflecting the annual NIPA revision.
row.Category: National, National income and product accounts (NIPAs)

row.Title: Fixed Assets and Consumer Durable Goods for 1995-2005
row.Author: David B. Wasshausen
row.Description: Estimates of the net stock of equipment and software and of structures owned by business and government and the net stock of durable goods owned by consumers-reflecting the annual NIPA revision.
row.Category: National, Fixed assets and consumer durable goods

row.Title: Foreign Direct Investment in the United States: Detail for Historical-Cost Position and Related Capital and Income Flows for 2002-2005
row.Author: Jeffrey H. Lowe
row.Description: Estimates of the direct investment position and international transactions by industry and country and the composition of investment by foreign companies in the United States. These estimates incorporate data from the 2002 benchmark survey.
row.Category: International, Foreign direct investment in the United States

row.Title: U.S. Direct Investment Abroad: Detail for Historical-Cost Position and Related Capital and Income Flows for 2003-2005
row.Author: Jeffrey H. Lowe
row.Description: Estimates of the direct investment position and international transactions of U.S. multinational companies and the composition of investment by U.S. companies abroad.

row.Title: Personal Income for Metropolitan Areas for 2005
row.Author: David G. Lenze
row.Description: Growth in both personal income and per capita income in most metropolitan areas slowed. The latest estimates reflect the effects of the hurricanes on the Gulf Coast, strong growth in the military sector, and weak growth in the auto industry.

row.Title: Director's Message
row.Author: J. Steven Landefeld
row.Description: Monthly message from BEA Director Steve Landefeld

row.Title: Taking Account
GDP and the Economy: Final Estimates for the Second Quarter of 2006
row.Author: Christopher Swann
row.Description: Real GDP increased 2.6 percent after increasing 5.6 percent. The deceleration reflected downturns in consumer spending for durable goods, in business investment in equipment and software, and in Federal Government spending and a deceleration in residential investment.
row.Category: National, National income and product accounts (NIPAs)

row.Title: Newly Available NIPA Tables
row.Description: Government current and capital expenditures by function, the relationship between NIPA Federal Government spending and Federal budget receipts and outlays and between NIPA state and local government spending and Census Bureau data, and seasonally unadjusted estimates.

row.Title: Real Inventories, Sales, and Inventory-Sales Ratios for Manufacturing and Trade for the Fourth Quarter of 2002 to the Second Quarter of 2006
row.Description: The estimates, including the estimates of inventories for manufacturing by stage of fabrication, have been updated to incorporate the results of the annual NIPA revision.

row.Title: U.S. International Services: Cross-Border Trade in 2005 and Sales Through Affiliates in 2004
row.Author: Jennifer Koncz, Michael Mann, Erin Nephew
row.Description: U.S. exports of services increased to $360.5 billion, and U.S. imports increased to $280.6 billion. Sales of services abroad by foreign affiliates of U.S. companies increased to $489.6 billion, and U.S. sales by U.S. affiliates of foreign companies increased to $382.8 billion
row.Supp1_Title: The 2004 Benchmark Survey of U.S. Direct Investment Abroad and the Treatment of Nonbank Units of U.S. Banks
row.Supp2_Title: New Measures of Insurance, Trade Services, and Financial Services Sold Through Affiliates

row.Title: U.S. International Transactions: Second Quarter of 2006
row.Author: Douglas B. Weinberg, Kelly K. Pierce, Erin M. Whitaker
row.Description: The U.S. current-account deficit increased $5.2 billion to $218.4 billion, mainly reflecting increases in the deficits on goods and on income. Net unilateral current transfers to foreigners increased. In the financial account, net financial flows decreased $17.5 billion to $154.1 billion

row.Title: State Personal Income: Second Quarter of 2006 and Revised Estimates for 2003-2005 and the First Quarter of 2006
row.Author: David G. Lenze
row.Description: Personal income growth for the Nation, slowed, increasing 1.7 percent after increasing 2.2 percent in the first quarter of 2006. Growth in all regions except the Great Lakes region slowed
row.Supp2_Title: Improved Preliminary State Estimates of Quarterly Wage and Salary Disbursements
row.Supp3_Title: Personal Income in the NIPAs and State Personal Income

row.Title: Director's Message
row.Author: J. Steven Landefeld
row.Description: Monthly message from BEA Director Steve Landefeld

row.Title: Taking Account
GDP and the Economy: Advance Estimates for the Third Quarter of 2006
row.Author: Christopher Swann
row.Description: Real GDP increased 1.6 percent after increasing 2.6 percent, reflecting an acceleration in imports, a downturn in inventory investment, a larger decrease in residential investment, and decelerations in consumer spending for services and state and local government spending.
row.Category: National, National income and product accounts (NIPAs)

row.Title: Newly Available NIPA Tables
row.Description: Comparison of income and outlays of nonprofit institutions serving households with IRS revenue and expenses of these nonprofit institutions, and personal income and its disposition by households and by nonprofit institutions serving households.
row.Category: National, National income and product accounts (NIPAs)

row.Title: Updated Summary of NIPA Methodologies
row.Description: The source data and methods used to prepare current-dollar and real estimates of GDP and current-dollar estimates of gross domestic income have been updated as part of the 2006 annual NIPA revision.
row.Category: National, National income and product accounts (NIPAs)

row.Title: Federal Personal Income Tax Liabilities and Payments for 19592004
row.Author: Mark A. Ledbetter
row.Description: These updated estimates incorporate the results of the 2006 annual NIPA revision, newly available IRS tax return data for 2002, and revised data for earned income tax credits.
row.Category: National, Federal personal income tax liabilities and payments

row.Title: Comparison of BEA Estimates of Personal Income and IRS Estimates of Adjusted Gross Income: New Estimates for 2004 and Revised Estimates for 2003
row.Author: Mark A. Ledbetter
row.Description: The estimates of these two widely used measures of household income are reconciled in order to account for statistical and definitional differences.
row.Category: National, National income and product accounts (NIPAs)

row.Title: Operations of U.S. Multinational Companies: Preliminary Results From the 2004 Benchmark Survey
row.Author: Raymond J. Mataloni Jr., Daniel R. Yorgason
row.Description: In 19992004, the value added of U.S. multinational companies grew at a 4-percent average annual rate. The value added of the U.S. parents grew 3 percent. And the value added of majority-owned foreign affiliates grew 8 percent.

row.Title: Reconciliation of the United StatesCanadian Current Account, 2004 and 2005
row.Author: Renee Sauers, Edward Dozier, Denis Caron
row.Description: Each year, the bilateral current-account estimates of the United States and Canada are reconciled to show how the estimates would appear if both countries used the same definitions, methodologies, and data sources.

row.Title: Director's Message
row.Author: J. Steven Landefeld
row.Description: Monthly message from BEA Director Steve Landefeld

row.Title: Taking Account
GDP and the Economy: Preliminary Estimates for the Third Quarter of 2006
row.Author: Christopher Swann
row.Description: Real GDP increased 2.2 percent after increasing 2.6 percent, reflecting an acceleration in imports, a larger decrease in residential investment, and decelerations in inventory investment, consumer spending for services, and state and local government spending. Corporate profits picked up.
row.Category: National, National income and product accounts (NIPAs)

row.Title: Government Receipts and Expenditures: Estimates for the Third Quarter of 2006
row.Author: Andrew P. Cairns
row.Description: Net government saving decreased $34.8 billion to -$171.7 billion. Net Federal Government saving decreased $6.6 billion to -$169.7 billion. Net state and local government saving decreased $28.1 billion to -$2.0 billion.
row.Category: National, National income and product accounts (NIPAs)

row.Title: BEA's 2006 Research and Development Satellite Account: Preliminary Estimates for 19592002 and Effect on GDP and Other Measures
row.Author: Sumiye Okubo, Carol A. Robbins, Carol E. Moylan, Brian K. Sliker, Laura I. Schultz, Lisa S. Mataloni
row.Description: The 2006 R&D satellite account marks another milestone in BEA's efforts to explore the effects of R&D on the economy. This article summarizes the key findings and discusses the key concepts behind the account.
row.Category: Industry, Research and development satellite account
row.Supp2_Title: Previous NIPA Improvements Related to R&D

row.Title: Annual Industry Accounts: Revised Estimates for 20032005
row.Author: Thomas F. Howells III, Kevin B. Barefoot, Brian M. Lindberg
row.Description: Real economic growth continued to be strong in 2005, mainly reflecting strong growth in the services-producing sector. Thirty-one of the thirty-six services-producing industries expanded in 2005. The goods sector also expanded in 2005.
row.Supp2_Title: Domestic Supply and Use of Oil and Gas Extraction and Petroleum and Coal Products

row.Title: Subject Guide for 2006
row.Description: This guide lists the articles that were published in the Survey in 2006.

row.Title: Schedule of News Release in 2007
